posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28212568
Two recommendations here.

One: Unironically, learn to meditate. The reason you liked shit more when you were younger was that it was new and your brain sucked it up like drugs. Tech, internet and culture have lead to 'skim' thinking (like skim reading). The consequence of that is that there's a lot more meat and juice still left in stuff you went over before, but you need concentration back again to get it.

Two: Supplement the above with introducing more novelty into your life. That could mean cooking new food, learning new skills, eating new spices, doing a sport. It doesn't really matter if you hated whatever it is when you were younger, so long as it's at least a little bit interesting, because the new factor will feed your brain that 'new' feeling. I know you know about getting hobbies, but that's basically why. New feeling stimulates the brain, and goes a way towards getting you interacting with life a bit more again.

>I started biking, which did make me feel way better
Keep doing it.

>>28212786
>Girls, if a long time friend (lets say 6+ months) asked you out and you weren't particularly interested in him, would you give him a shot or shoot him down?
I've probably already considered whether I'd hypothetically date him or not. And being hypothetically willing to date isn't the same as being actively interested, so I might give it a whirl.
But if it seems like he's been outright pining for me and I haven't felt a reciprocal urge, I wouldn't, because that just feels like I'd be stringing him along. I also might not if I think the friendship has more value to me than a potential relationship (like, if I'm not particularly interested AND there seem to be blatant incompatibilities).

But in the scenario of "friend asks me out, I had no idea until now that he'd do so, there aren't any obvious dealbreakers, I'm not actively UNattracted to him, and there'd be no catastrophic social fallout if things got a little awkward in the event of a bad date" then sure, why not, let's hang out and see.

You need a reason or endpoint other than "I no longer use porn" or "I need to not fap".

I don't say that to steer you back to the status quo, I say that as someone that has quit tons of this stuff (porn, Youtube, social media, etc). Some of the things I've quit, some I re-added back in at smaller amounts. There was a point where all of it was gone and I was just constantly bored as shit, even with productive hobbies.

If you don't have a better reason like:

- There is a specific hobby that I want to pursue, I already know what that hobby is, and the steps involved to start it, but I'm looking at porn for 6 hours a day
- I want to decrease my focus on sex so that I can pursue vocational training/get better grades/get a Masters/become a classical violinist
- I have to think about porn during actual sex
- Basic sex stuff doesn't get me hard

Then don't bother. You'll just increase your boredom and have one less thing that makes you happy. It's nice to know that you have above average willpower and discipline if you succeed, but it mostly just makes life more boring and less colourful.

I can't recommend it highly enough.
Waiting a little bit helps only a little bit, because a few months in the grand scheme of things is very little.
Lurk this board for a while and you'll see some thread of a guy who wants to break up with a long-term gf he's been stringing along for *years* (or trashes an ex), includes a list of pros and cons, and 9 times out of 10, at the top of the "pros" list, he puts 'sex is nice'. Many guys are content to stay in a dead-end relationship just because it's convenient, and they'll happily take up most of a woman's youth if they're allowed to. This is something you'd never be able to prevent if you only wait for a set period of time instead of expecting commitment.

Meanwhile, if you wait, you're basing the relationship entirely on how much you like each other as people. If you don't get along and he knows there's no way he'll get sex without committing (users are loathe to do that), he'll save you a lot of time and heartache and move on quickly himself. It might get demoralizing seeing guys bail on hearing it, but if you're dating to find a compatible partner, they are doing you a favor.
Waiting until marriage also selects exclusively for guys who put commitment before sex, rather than the other way around--and it gives you a way to test a guy's intentions, because the duplicitous ones will try to pressure you either for sex or some sexual "compromise" so he can still get himself off without commitment.

And there's nothing like the intimacy of knowing that you and your spouse have only been with each other. That's something you can only count on if you wait, and it's just sad that so many people convince themselves that this romantic ideal is unattainable today. There are plenty of very good reasons to wait besides the ones I've listed. Please don't miss out on the chance for something beautiful just because it seems odd or rare--it's doable and very worth it. Pic related. She's probably married by now.

You have to look at any job application from the employers perspective. What is it that YOU can bring to THEM? How does hiring YOU benefit THEM? And here's the clincher, how does the benefits YOU bring stack up against or compete with ALL THE OTHER CANDIDATES?

Btw, "they get an employee" is not an answer to that question. So you need to start at the absolute bottom in a shithole dead end job where they need employee scale but face high turnover so basically everyone who applies gets hired. That's where you need to focus your applications. Build up some work experience over 18 months and you'll be in a much better position to get employed somewhere else.

Remember, a paper qualification is meaningless in 2023 without experience.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28101153
A job change isn't going to fix your life. You need an entire lifestyle change. I'm 26 and went through something similar around 24. I'm going to recommend something cliche, but it fucking works for reasons I will elaborate on. Get in shape. If you are fat lose weight. If you are skinny hit the gym. Yes it's a physical thing but we are mostly after the mental benefits. When you improve physically it does several things mentally (arguably it has more mental benefits than physical). First is you learn to be disciplined. This obviously effects every aspect of life. You need discipline to escape NEETdom. Next it will give you a taste of that "better life". You will see hard effort turn into tangible rewards that you can be proud of. This can set off a chain reaction into other aspects of life you feel are lacking. Next is confidence. You will be more confident in your self and your abilities and it could be enough of a boost to get you to pounce on opportunities you otherwise would have missed by being passive. Perhaps most important of all it will get you out of the house and give you a hobby that isn't doing anything for you. This can lead to meeting new people and gives you a common interest hobby that you can share and engage with most people over. Don't forget other people will treat you better too.

All of that doesn't even take into account the physical aspects that also play a role in mental health. You would likely see an increase in certain hormones such as testosterone and a decrease in things like estrogen. These hormones play a huge role in mental health and having screwed up hormones probably play a huge role in depression and the like. In my opinion physical improvement is the number one best thing you can do if you are unhappy with your life because it lays the foundation for everything else. This is coming from someone who was fat basically my entire life and was well on my way to being an eternal neet. Getting /fit/ is what saved me.

>>28176244
I can't read it. My specific situation will not really relate to you.

The TL;DR is that I am an /out/ist through and through and nothing is going to change that.

I was in the army before college. Biology degree. Wildly depressed, and medicated for it. In college I did an internship with a conservation agency and it was fun, but I did the "right thing" and after school I just kept pursuing my "career path." Nothing glamorous or financially enticing, mind you. At 27 I had a paradigm shift, some major life changes (sister offed herself and ended a toxic 6 year relationship) and I took some seasonal /out/ work in Alaska to try and clear my heart and my head. Quit taking Zoloft during this time.

Following this, I left and did a "normal" job for about 1.25 years before I again felt the urge to get the fuck back outside. I worked for an environmental compliance contractor. I had a moment of clarity when a guy who had been there for 12 years told me he had a zoology degree. It made me sad to know he once shared my dreams. So I had to leave. Almost every person I knew told me that, at ~28 it was too late for a "career change" and I should just stay in place and effectively work at the same place until I died. I've since worked for a few different agencies/places for the feds doing /out/ things. I do not make much money. My job security is tenuous. But I feel at peace and wouldn't change it.

The point of my story is simply that if you recognize something you are truly passionate about, you should just stick with it, because trying to convince yourself you are happier in some other capacity just results in you being miserable. I wouldn't do something just to feel like you're moving forward, if that makes sense. I wouldn't do something you aren't "super passionate" about. Do not go be a cop simply because it is SOMETHING. Its your life, anon. 1/4 of it is over. Do you want to waste another 1/2 doing something you don't even give a shit about?

To put it as bluntly and simply as possible, passion projects are for trust fund kids, those who have already made it, and regular people who have exceptional talent and drive. The general rule is that if you were in the latter group, you would know by 25 ie you would already have been grinding for years at that point and you'd start to see success. Sorry to say, that's not you, so on to step two.

Step two is employment, which mostly sucks. Some people will tell you about how they have a passion for making other people rich, but they're mostly just coping. The purpose of employment is to GET CASH FLOW so you can either exit employment or at least have the funds to cope with it and stay sane. You should find something you're good at that you can tolerate without burning out that MAXIMIZES cash flow and pursue that. Ideally it should pay you to learn skills that you can deploy outside of employment so you can exit employment sooner rather than later. Think of employment as a bridge from virgin neetdom to chad neetdom. Some examples of viable options are trades, sales, it, coding meme, internet marketing. You can get an entry-level job in most of these fields with little-to-no experience. Grind certs, lie, just do whatever you need to do. Then start accruing skills that you can use for freelancing, consulting, contracting, ect in order to exit employment. If you really want to you can do your art fag stuff on the side, and if that blows up and you stop showing up to your job, more power to you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Leave him alone. Call an emergency animal hospital and take him in to be boarded or placed properly in a carrier you can remove easily from the car and place on the ground.

Struggling with this dog, there's a chance you could open up the wound and kill him. There's a very good chance he could bite you horribly if you hurt him suddenly while trying to move him.

This next part is probably not helpful. Just skip to the bottom.

If you absolutely must move him, your best bet is to provide him with some sort of a ramp and then lure him down to the ground with food and water. Roll him gently onto a blanket and then pull the blanket into a box or carrier. If you can't get him to roll, but the wound isn't against the floor of the hatchback, fold a big piece of cardboard so that you have a soft edge, then push that under him. Now push another box under that, wrap it around the dog, and tape it so that he cannot roll off the edge, but NOT so securely that he could injure his legs if you fuck this up. What you need now is a tabletop and something you can use to make a ramp with it. Don't just stack something up as you could have a real disaster when his weight makes the bottom of the table slide. Ideally what you want is the upper end propped on some tires or a dirt mound, and the bottom of it somewhere you can leave him for the night or drag him away while still on the box.

What you really need to do is call your local emergency vet, drive the dog there, and board him. Why the fuck did they not give him to you in a carrier?

it absolutely will not be replaced with AI. autopilot can handle the flying part, but you will never be able to safely land or take-off an aircraft without a human operator. the boeing 737 MAX disaster was caused by the flight software taking over from the pilots who weren't trained in how to disable it.

however, being a pilot is a difficult career to get into. if you've ever been diagnosed with a serious mental illness (personality disorder, bipolar disorder, any form of psychosis) you're disqualified from piloting commercial aircraft. there are also health requirements. if you need glasses you'll need to prove that your vision can be corrected to near-normal with your glasses.

but, if you're mentally and physically healthy, then yes, a pilot is a great career choice.

You can't force it. These guys are not trying hard to be funny or impress those girls. They are just feeling confident in their own skin and being themselves, killing some time by talking shit with people. It's not the mechanical utterance of a joke that is funny itself but the flow of conversation, the person, the character and the natural delivery and timing which can't be intellectually learned or understood. You have to be able to connect to the energy of the group or person, feel at peace and comfortable with yourself to let yourself go. Not everybody was born to be the comedian so if you are more quiet and reserved that's fine. Worst thing you can do is try to force yourself to be funny and fake confidence. It makes you look lame and desperate for attention because you need external approval to feel good about yourself. Being funny is like a special life memory, significant moment or experience of having great fun. It can't be predicted or planned. It just happens naturally. It is the same with most things in life and it is definitely so with a good joke that takes over the groups consciousness and drives everyone into hysterical laughter.

How do you deal with the pervasive sense of anxiety you get that
>there are things you could or should be doing, but you don't - because you never seem to find the time, the effort, the mood or the motivation, or maybe the thought of doing that thing itself stirs up anxiety,
>your life isn't quite on the right track but you're not sure what you can do to change things

I suppose the thing is I get the sense my life isn't quite what it should be, and it chews me up inside, but it's hard to know where to even begin trying to tackle all these things, especially when you're in a crappy mood. And then, I'm not so sure doing those things that I do have in mind will even help. Perhaps it's the way of thinking that's the problem, and I need to somehow find a way to accept things as they are, even if they could be better.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Your ability to do things in life is mostly the way you choose to deal with happenings as they come. The mindset of someone who says they can't do something because they're in a bad mood, will be more limited than someone who thinks "I'm in a bad mood, ok, let's walk away for a bit and then come back and try to tackle as much of this as I can" as their default. Knowing how to ask questions to the problems you face are a great boon to solving them in the first place, since ignorance is half the problem. If you feel you're unsure how to tackle doing the things you want, you should definitely spend time learning how to ask questions. Contextualizing the problem into a coherent question to solve is invaluable.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28210981
I used to have this and still may get these thoughts but this problem can't get a hold of you if you understand that at the end of the day there is nothing to be gained or lost. I used to look out the window in class and feel like I am traped and that there is people out there beyond my field of vision actually living life. It's hard to explain but it was like I had a strong energy, motivation and will to go out there and grind at something meaningful but there was nothing to do that seemed like "it" so I constantly thought I am wasting my time, my youth and my life. It came down to "I need/want xyz and then I will be happy". Now I realise that these people that I am jealous of because of their "success" did not "make it". There is no such thing as making it. I gave too much importance to things I didn't have because I thought if I had this body, this skill, job, house, gf, friends I would be happy and live happily ever after. This is bullshit. There is no finish line of "making it" where you can say that's it, I don't have to work or do anything anymore. Think of life like sandbox rpg where you have limited time of play until your character dies and you have to make a new one. Only as an aesthetic phenomenon are existence and the world justified. We are just here to play and have fun but there is no reward for anything except the reward of achieveing the things themselves. This is not a call to laziness and consumerism but a call to realistic ambition and a balanced life. People are worth what they get when you take away everything they have. You are worth what you are. Friends come and go, people die, life changes, time goes by, you can lose your job, your wealth and your health but rooting yourself on that which never changes is what gives you eternal peace of mind and strength. Consider the things you think you want to have or achieve and put yourself in the position of a person that already has these things. If it's worth the effort pursue it...

kek. It's over faggot. Might as well rope now if you're insisting on going down this route.

Could be months, could be years, could be never, before you get yourself a job with a wage that would allow you to survive, depending on where you're moving to.

You sort EVERYTHING out BEFORE you move. You apply for jobs and get yourself a bunch of interviews lined up. You travel to the new place and stay on a hotel for a week or two to do the interviews. If you don't get a job offer you come back and rinse repeat. If you do get a job offer that is decent enough, you extend your stay, start moving your shit and look for a place to live.

You don't move anywhere until you have a job waiting for you. Yes, all this travel back and forth costs money. That's the point. Moving cities is expensive, so it has to be a consideration in your decision making.

I went to bed super early so I woke up super early.
Ate the last of my braised meat with mashed potatoes, for any aspiring home cooks I highly recommend going the extra mile with braising, its not hard but
>Browning the outside of the meat before braising or slow cooking. Braising doesn't get high enough temperature to brown the entirely outside so you miss out on complex flavors by not doing this
>Cooking aromatics like Mirepoix( Carrots, Celery, Onions) and others like Garlic goes a long way in enhancing the flavor. I just discord the mushy vegetables at the end when I strain the liquid
>Cook down the braising liquid until it gets thick and turns into a sauce, tastes very good and the collogen release from the meat naturally acts as a thickening agent for it as long as you reduce the liquid out of it enough
Braising is easily the best way to get a high quality meal at home, none of the skills are intensive and 95% of the work is hands off.
